column4: Yorkville is a fun place to visit in Toronto. It can be quite pricey, so you may need to do more window shopping than shopping, but it really is a beautiful place to grab a coffee and take a walk.

A very artistic place located in the middle of Toronto. Very different to the city itself, it plays host to the artists of the area. Fantastic art shops with little cafes and restaurants. Its a beautiful place to visit but be careful of the spending as it can get very expensive.
I enjoy this area in the summer, book early if you want to eat, it is very busy. It is a place to be seen

This area is for expensive tastes. Well worth going and walking along. A few condo buildings have been erected in the past few years, which has spoilt the area. Used to be a lot nicer. Very popular for tourists and worth going to see.
Shopping galore. Restaurants everywhere. Extremely busy especially when the winters over. Might say this is the place The Fashionable Visit.
I like this neighbor as it is convenient to a lot of shops and restaurants, museums and University of Toronto. It is an area suitable for walking.

Yorkville is a great area to walk through but they are changing. All the stores that once made it great are being closed to make way for condos.There is still plenty to see and do but not like there was before. Even TIFF bailed on the area a few years ago in favor of King Street and the entertainment...

The streets in Yorkville are very fun and clean to walk around and do a little shopping. There are plenty of windows to look at and also many restaurants and bars to stop at along the way. This is one of my favourite areas of the city.

I left Toronto and moved west nearly 40 years ago. Yorkville was changing then from its 1960's hippie scene which I frequented often. Great bars; music venues; strange people, and the occasional celebrity sighting..Yorkville was Canada's Haight Ashbury. Today all of that is gone. High end stores, unique shops and a variety of restaurants , patios and people watching . A glass of wine on an outdoor patio makes for an interesting afternoon watching the world go by.
Back in the 60's this was hippy town that now got transferred to yuppy town. Not quite what it used to be because of all the construction and high-rise building going on.
there are a very wide variety of restaurants here most a little priceythere is also mega shopping at most price levelsthe people watching is off the charts

great to walk around and visit the different small shops and the fancy small shopping centre. make sure you go for lunch or dinner in one of the cafes. if the weather is good i suggest to get an outdoor table. a place to watch fashion.it is a high class, european style street.

We always go walking on Yorkville.Went there yesterday even with the snow it is beautiful.Great restaurants and coffee bars.Can walk to young street and blood from there.Also walk to parallel Cumberland crescent.

Love Yorkville as tons of unique shops and restaurants. Explore all around Yorkville and Cumberland streets. Stop for afternoon tea at the Four Seasons or Windsor Arms or hit the spa at various hotels or shops. Take in a movie or hit one of the bars offering music and bands.

We were driving guests from out of town through Toronto late at night and drove through Yorkville. It was lit up all over the place soon after Christmas was over. I hadn't been there in over 20 years and was pleasantly surprised at how much development there was and is now one of my favorite spots to go dine on...
Yorkville is a nice area of Toronto to visit. During the week there are lots of shops available as well as restaurants to pick from any culture. Just bring your big wallet :)

Lots of unique stores and good restaurants. If not the most, one of the more expensive areas in TO. Some good restaurants however the location results in higher prices.Many well-heeled people frequent the area. One downside is some of the people you meet are showy, pay too much attention to brands and too interested in status/wealth.

Nice area. Lovely walks through university grounds. Try it, some cool buildings. Lots of high end shops if you like that sort of thing but character comes from the buildings along the street and churches dotted around.

This is what Yorkville is for. Showing your fancy cars and spending money on designer clothes. Style for sale. Sorry, as a Toronto born citizen, Yorkville is a loss from the coolest to the least cool. There are some good restaurants and ice cream though.
Centrally located , subway or bus can get you to Yonge and Bloor area. Short block north. Trendy restaurants, boutiques, bars . Some interesting stores to see.

Lot's of high end boutiques, stores, restaurants etc where you can drop a load $$$. There are some more reasonably priced establishments as well. The Nespresso cafe is a place to grab a nice Espresso or Latte and a danish. Hemingways rooftop patio is a great place for brunch in the warmer months.
Yorkville is an upper-scale avenue that holds posh shops with expensive restaurants. There is an abundance of coffee shops and stores. A beautiful place to be.
near my school and home! I always go there for gelato! nice litte shopping and dinning area to visit.
Great to stroll the streets and window shop, some of the nicest shops in Toronto. Known as the Fifth Avenue of Toronto.

This was perhaps our favorite area we visited while in Toronto. It is definitely an upscale, but not "snooty", part of town. The area is full of fun shops and art galleries (the best art gallery options in Toronto, especially featuring Canadian artists), as well as bars and restaurants. We loved simply walking around the area. Put this area on...
Very enjoyable walking around in this neighborhood with tns of chic shops, nice chic visitors and good small food places and good eating too.

wasn't what you would call part of it ,,,but remember many times walking through yorkville ,,,was so quiet , peaceful ,,unreal ,,,changed a lot over the years ,,but , memories still there ,,,like to go by for a visit when i'm around ,,,memory lane

Bring your wallet, there are lots of amazing stores in 1 km radius. You will not leave empty-handed-I assure you! Check out Sorry coffee or Tutti for great coffee.
Yorkville is like most of the world's high-end shopping districts. It has a nice selection of shops, but for those people living in the world's major cities, it can easily be skipped.

Quaint little section of the city. Very exclusive and expensive and it feels like it! Great coffee shops and one of the best deli's in the city -Pusateri's. Yorkvilke is the place to people watch and be seen. Cute streets and back alleys, fantastic bistros and a fine spit to celeb watch.

It's just a street. Nothing special. Sometimes on summer nights, it has a European feel because of street performers. Other than that, just insanely priced boutiques and shops (not for the sane). Not even a nice place for a stroll.
Yorkville is a great place to browse and people watch. Some rather expensive shops but great to look, see how the other half live. Great places to eat and drink. Would definitely visit again.
This is a great spot to just walk and browse around. Lots of unique interesting shops, boutiques and eateries - very elite and expense but nice to just look around once and a while.
If you are visiting Toronto, stay in this area, it is such a hip fun area! Great high end stores even a Guerlan make up store, very rare is here and lots of things to do all day
Many wonderful boutique shopsFun to walk around and observe all activitiesGreat variety of choices in restaurants

Put on your fanciest outfit when you visit this part of town or you'll most likely feel out of place! Some of Bay Street's highest rollers dwell in these condos and I'm sure there are a few celebrities that live there too!Morton's steakhouse is delicious!
It is New York 5th Avenue....lots of nice restaurants, nice, but expensive boutiques. It has Europian feeling.

High end shops, restaurants, hotels and more. Great place to go shooping. Yorkville is where all the celebrity sightings are during the yearly TIFF festival

Once a small area of Toronto that spanned about 3 by 5 blocks, it had wonderful character, old homes, and an artsy feel. Over rated...so called 'high end' experience - meh. Come and people watch and see their expressions of 'could be somewhere else'. Good restaurants and some great shopping. Even a nice urban garden. You can find a few nice outdoor eating places.Currently there is a lot of construction going on. Hopefully the caracter of the neighborhood will stay the same.The area would be great as a pedestrian only zone.

This particular area including famous Bloor street was a tiny village in 1830. bit of a letdown.. just more for people who are into shopping. nothing new or different about it from anywhere else in the US.
Cool paces to hang out , for food, drinks, shopping experience, Equinox gym and much more a nice eye candy place
great place to have a walk. If you have limited time in toronto, do not bother to there. Like a small europe town.

Yet another area to buy Chanel, Hermes etc. Every big city has this area, which is nothing exciting unless you are going for it.But Yorkville has a nice little village with a very interesting park/gardens.

It's Toronto equivalent to Rodeo Dr in LA though on a much smaller scale and with less hype and fanfare. It is located slightly north of the city and is accessible by public transport. Take a walk through here but keep going. This place is interesting but I wouldn't recommend doing anything here other than walking through.

make sure you eat at Vatticano..Best Italian in city..Park Hyatt has great rooftop lounge. Hemmingways great for lunch. Everything right there
Beautiful place to window shop and purchase if the price is right for you. High end shops and hotels Restaurants and coffee shops Lovely to walk around and enjoy the history and architecture.

Definitely a must go and see.Worth a stroll, even if only for window shopping.....just check out the nice shop windows and enjoy people watching. Sit down on the cumberland parkette on the massive rock.
I really enjoy this area for people watching, trendy restaurants, and great shopping. All the high end stores and boutiques are in this area
This is a very affluent area of Toronto. Only drove through on the Hop on Hop off bus with live commentary and sounded a good place.

The Yorkville area (loosely bordered by Yonge-Bloor-Avenue Rd-Yorkville Ave) is more than just swanky retail stores (though there are plenty - Tiffany, Louis Vuitton, Chanel and so on). So much fun to walk around and people watch, beautiful shopping, great restaurants, especially the night life! Everyone comes out dresses to the nines! We loved it!!

So manicured, it's lost its charm. Also, now that the Film Festival has moved from there, this area holds less interest for many. Hazleton Lanes could be anywhere. Great area for shopping, dining and walking around. Very nice and trendy neighborhood with lots of people traffic.

The area is loaded with shops, and the chance to see the area is a great plus. Do get a little something to remember the trip, we have been there several times and of course we often visit many of our favorite places.
Great place to "see" and "be seen"....super shops and wonderful restaurants......check out Il Posto...stores are a bit pricey but fun.....parking in the surrounding streets
Many good restaurants with good wine selection, as well as upscale boutiques. Great to walk around on a nice day and people watch.

Torontos most expensive area, great for people watching .may even see some one famous.especially in sept during TIFF Luxury Item Stores. Good English Pub , Great Italian Gellato, luxury cars driving around just to be seen.
Great place to walk and explore. Restaurants, Treats and lots of Shopping! Very nicely done. Really nothing of the Big Stores missing.

The Irish are renowned for their charm,friendliness and good will but we have a firm contender in Toronto one will have to go here to experience this for themselves what an amazing city from sightseeing to shopping fine dining and off course the people make this the ideal choice to holiday in Canada

Located just north of Bloor and Avenue Roads, is the lovely enclave of Yorkville. Yorkville is such a pretty area of downtown Toronto. Lots of high- end shops, cafes, and outdoor terraces. A great place to spend time with friends.
It's a great place to explore. Not too far from the ROM (Royal Ontario Museum) either. Most restaurants are quite pricey but I loved taking a walk around the area. Great part of Toronto to see.

Yorkville is an excellent place for high end shopping as well as great choices for good quality food and drinks. There are great walkways and tons of parking areas. Highly recommended to check this neighborhood out!
Great area for people who want to see high end shops. There are mostly just main stream businesses here nothing really local.

Ok ... If you are looking for a $5,000 handbag to round out your wardrobe this is your spot.If you want interesting sightseeing, go elsewhere. Yorkville used to be such a cool, interesting, bohemian area of the city but not anymore. It has been upscaled to death.

On a pleasant summer day, Yorkville is a 2-hour max. visit, then coffee, or ice cream, or lunch, or dinner. Yorkwille is a nice place to visit for visitors to Toronto. Nice stores, boutiques, restaurants. Beautiful homes, nice architecture.
Nice part of Toronto with expensive stores, many restaurants and park. It is nice just to walk around and look in the store windows or set in the park.

I still do not like this place. I am not a member of the affluent part of humanity. Many different stores have appeared and many more have disappeared since my last visit here. A really nice area to explore on foot. Lots of treny (expensive) stores and some nice restaurants as well. A must see!!!

A great place to walk through & window shop or grab a coffee & enjoy the scenery. Festivals are held here throughout the year that attract people from all over to enjoy the food & elegance of Yorkville.

Yorkville is a pretty stuffy area, but fun to walk around and visit. Restaurants and service are a hit and miss in the area, some places are so snobby and ritzy but there are some fun, laid back pubs too! I would recommend Hemingways for some food and drinks.
This is the place to visit where you might bump into some celebrities or see the filming of some movie. Great restaurants with patios, and nice upper end shopping.

If you feel like a great street stroll to go shopping or Dining you have come to the right neighbourhood. with its high end shops and restaurants, window shopping is like going to a museum. the art and decor that some shops put together is eye candy and fun to see as you stroll down the busy few blocks around Yorkville, including Belair, Cumberland and Hazelton. It is such a nice place to walk through. So many small stores with such unique things. You can always find something for that person who has everything. Nice cafes!

Better dining experiences elsewhere in diverse Toronto and friendly places. (I work in the area!)
I had lunch once in Yorkville at a fabulous Indian Restaurant. I don't remeber the name but it was so great!

Nice area and worth visiting at least once when in Toronto. Should have a short walk to enjoy the shops and restaurants.
Alwas visit Yorkville when in Toronto. Really enjoy the market in Hazeltown Mall. Lots of shops and restaurants.

I love coming to Yorkville. Changing over the years. Still great place to stroll. Lots of over priced upscale shops. Buy your wife an original Louis Vitton purse. Great restaurants. Great people watching.
